fields.headline: Arts briefing
fields.bodyText: · Chris Wise, the engineer who created the wobbly Millennium bridge, has designed a new footbridge for Stockton-on-Tees. And this time he says he's determined to make "bloody sure" there's no swaying. He told Building magazine: "The analysis tools available to engineers were far more limited five years ago." · Joan Bakewell has been appointed as the new head of the National Campaign for the Arts - the lobbying group that spans all the arts in the UK. Bakewell, a Guardian columnist and former arts correspondent for the BBC, said: "I look forward to joining the board in promoting the case of the arts with vigour and enthusiasm - especially in the build-up to the election." · Ludo Kesten, the chief executive at York's Theatre Royal, is joining the Royal Shakespeare Company in the newly created post of general manager. Starting in the new year, he will work across RSC productions in London and Stratford. · Bollywood choreographer Honey Kalaria is opening three new dance centres in London. Kalaria, who was one of the judges of Channel 4's Search for a Bollywood Star, already has 11 centres, but aims to open more in "most of the major cities" across the UK. · A new competition has been launched to improve the state of British cemeteries. The Association of Burial Authorities has launched the Phoenix awards scheme, open to anyone who has ideas on how to turn "dull" British cemeteries into attractive places for quiet recreation."It's time we brought them into the 21st century," says chair Sam Weller. · The Chinese martial arts film Hero is having a surprisingly good run at the American box office. The film, directed by Raise the Red Lantern's Zhang Yimou and starring Jet Li and Tony Leung, has topped the charts for a second week. It boasts the second-biggest opening in America for a foreign-language film, second only to Mel Gibson's The Passion of the Christ.
